III.    Facility Identification

The Berkshire Refrigerated Warehousing facility is located at 4550 South Packers Avenue in Chicago, Illinois. The NAICS code for the facility is 49312 - Refrigerated Warehousing and Storage. 



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for cold storage. 



The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 15,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool the blast freezers, holding freezer, convertible freezers, north and south freezer, shipping docks, and boxing room, ready-to-eat room. This system is a two stage system with three (3) low stage and two (2) high stage compressors.  Evaporators are fed with high pressure liquid from the receiver, through the low and high temperature recirculators.



An aerial photo identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Man

agement Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Berkshire is continuously improving this program. 



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on February 2-4, 2021, and the next audit will occur before February 4, 2024, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Berkshire has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?    Process Safety Information - Berkshire maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. 

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Berkshire has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Berkshire conducted a thorough PHA revalidation study for the ammonia refrigeration system on January 26, 27, and 28, 2022.

?    Operating Procedures - Berkshire has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly main

tained.  Berkshire developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during December 2004. Operating procedures were most recently reviewed and certified on February 18, 2022.

?    Training - Berkshire has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems. However, refrigeration contractors are currently relied upon to operate and maintain the syste,

 

?    Management of Change - Berkshire has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 

?    Pre-Startup Review - Berkshire has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Berkshire has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  

?    Contractor Qualifications - Berkshire has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Berkshire Refrigerated Warehousing and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Berkshire has developed a site-specific inc

ident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. No ammonia releases have been reported within the past five (5) years.

?    Compliance Audit - Berkshire has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Berkshire PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The two most recent compliance audits were completed February 2, 3, and 4, 2021.    

?    Hot Work Permits - Berkshire has developed a best management practice for hot work.  

 



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Berkshire facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years. 



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Berkshire has developed an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  



Berkshire has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the Chicago Fire Department HAZMAT Team.  



Berkshire has coordinated their emergency action plan with the Cook County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Chicago Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our emergency action plan, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information

.



Although Berkshire does not have an onsite hazardous materials response team, selected individuals have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training, and drills.  The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.  



The facility has one (1) windsock present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.



The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.

 



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Berkshire operations. Berkshire recently conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) of their ammonia refrigeration system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that PHA. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Berkshire.  



XI.    Management Program

Berkshire has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Ted Grzywacz, President of Berkshire Refrigerated Warehousing, LLC is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
